articles.headline: Europe Feels the Squeeze of the Trump Trade Tariffs
articles.snippet: Business managers worry whether a cease-fire between Brussels and the White House will hold. The uncertainty is bad for growth.
articles.abstract: Business managers worry whether a cease-fire between Brussels and the White House will hold. The uncertainty is bad for growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Higher prices. Disrupted supply chains. Wavering exports.

articles.headline: Apple’s $1 Trillion Milestone Reflects Rise of Powerful Megacompanies
articles.snippet: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
articles.abstract: Apple is part of a group of giant companies that dominate the United States economy. That is good for financial markets, but not necessarily for everyone else.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel. General Motors. AT&T. Exxon Mobil.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Expanding Power to Block Chinese Firms. HNA Was Already No Match.
articles.snippet: High-level meetings, powerful lobbying firms and a charm offensive were unable to get regulators to approve a deal with SkyBridge Capital, Anthony Scaramucci’s firm.
articles.abstract: High-level meetings, powerful lobbying firms and a charm offensive were unable to get regulators to approve a deal with SkyBridge Capital, Anthony Scaramucci’s firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just over a year ago, two senior executives from the giant Chinese conglomerate HNA landed a meeting with Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, at his office. The executives, Adam Tan and Guang Yang, snapped a photo with Mr. Mnuchin, holding a model plane of the HNA-owned carrier, Hainan Airlines.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: Workers Hardest Hit by Recession Are Joining in Recovery
articles.snippet: Unemployment among those without a high school diploma has declined by two-thirds since the economy’s low point, the latest jobs report shows.
articles.abstract: Unemployment among those without a high school diploma has declined by two-thirds since the economy’s low point, the latest jobs report shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The least educated American workers, who took the hardest hit in the Great Recession, were also among the slowest to harvest the gains of the recovery. Now they are a striking symbol of a strong economy.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Democrats See an Opening in Kansas if Trump Ally Wins Primary
articles.snippet: Kris Kobach, a hard-line Trump supporter, could win the Republican nomination for governor, creating intraparty clashes over whether he’s too extreme.
articles.abstract: Kris Kobach, a hard-line Trump supporter, could win the Republican nomination for governor, creating intraparty clashes over whether he’s too extreme.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The evolution of the Kansas Republican Party mirrors that of the national party, a rightward shift from the moderation of Dwight D. Eisenhower to the mainstream conservatism of Bob Dole to the small-government absolutism of former Gov. Sam Brownback and Wichita-based Koch Industries.

articles.headline: Pope’s Death Penalty Stance Won’t Stop Execution, Nebraska’s Catholic Governor Says
articles.snippet: After years of battling over capital punishment, the state has scheduled what would be its first execution in 21 years for later this month.
articles.abstract: After years of battling over capital punishment, the state has scheduled what would be its first execution in 21 years for later this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — When Nebraska lawmakers defied Gov. Pete Ricketts in 2015 by repealing the death penalty over his strong objections, the governor wouldn’t let the matter go. Mr. Ricketts, a Republican who is Roman Catholic, tapped his family fortune to help bankroll a referendum to reinstate capital punishment, a measure the state’s Catholic leadership vehemently opposed.

articles.headline: Follow the Money (Then Take a Picture)
articles.snippet: With “Generation Wealth,” the filmmaker Lauren Greenfield looks back at 30 years of chronicling the rich — and predicting our cultural future.
articles.abstract: With “Generation Wealth,” the filmmaker Lauren Greenfield looks back at 30 years of chronicling the rich — and predicting our cultural future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps because she has spent her career watching the rich, the photographer and filmmaker Lauren Greenfield is herself rich to watch. At a party after the New York premiere of her new documentary — “Generation Wealth,” about the perils of capitalism — Ms. Greenfield was wired, welcoming and constantly working. She snapped pictures of the well-heeled crowd as she hugged her way around the room, occasionally misplacing a glass of white wine, in a churn of compliments and gossip.

articles.headline: How Tech Billionaires Hack Their Taxes With a Philanthropic Loophole
articles.snippet: A trendy maneuver allows wealthy donors to reap immediate tax benefits, while charities can wait for funds indefinitely — or even forever.
articles.abstract: A trendy maneuver allows wealthy donors to reap immediate tax benefits, while charities can wait for funds indefinitely — or even forever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late in 2014, Nicholas Woodman, the founder and chief executive of GoPro, announced what appeared to be an extraordinary act of generosity.

articles.headline: China Threatens New Tariffs on $60 Billion of U.S. Goods
articles.snippet: The new threat comes after President Trump asked his administration to consider more than doubling tariffs on $200 billion a year of Chinese goods.
articles.abstract: The new threat comes after President Trump asked his administration to consider more than doubling tariffs on $200 billion a year of Chinese goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China threatened on Friday to tax an additional $60 billion a year worth of imports from the United States if the Trump administration imposes its own new levies on Chinese goods.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Cao Li
